pullRequest.title: [RW-4561][risk=no] factor out pdf viewer
pullRequest.bodyText:
Factor out the PDF viewer component from the account creation component. Unfortunately, I had to put an amount of the 'look, we've viewed the last page' stuff into the PDF viewer but most of it I was able to keep in the account creation component.

PR checklist

 This PR includes appropriate unit tests
 I have run and tested this change locally

nodes.bodyText: nit: check the IDE settings to insert a newline before EOF

thinking out loud: Is there a way to test actual content on the pages? This kinda feels like we're saying "there are 10 pages. How many pages are there? 10? good." Not sure how much is really getting covered by this test I guess, but it may be all you can really do here.
Could you have a /test/assets/documents/pdf1.pdf or something and test with a real doc?
aside: why isn't this the preferred way to do all the styles? Just a TSX style thing?
It's not obvious by the name inputRef that it has to do with last page handling. Are you just using this property assignment for its side effect of calling setLastPageRef()?
nit: it feels redundant to have an index, a page number, and a key like page_99. Do we really need all three? If so, it would help to have unit tests to make sure they are always in sync.
What's the difference between {false} and false?
nit: I'd spell out terms-of-service or make it more general like pdf-page. That is, is there anything TOS-specific about this component?
instead of undefined, could you define a stub method to just demonstrate that it gets called and nothing happens? That feels safer too, since you don't have to test for undefined before calling.
Is it necessary to pass in the windowSize if we're using withWindowSize() in the component? Or we can keep this and remove the withWindowSize()

the rest of the stuff in handleLastPageRender() looks like stuff that might be able to go into the shared component.
I don't fully understand how it works but I think, ultimately, components that use the PdfViewer component just want to know when the user has read the entire PDF and not concern themselves with stuff like IntersectionObserverCallback.
Per slack discussion, it appears that in order to trigger the event property you need to call simulate() on the input rather than the CheckBox element.
